metadata.titleEn: 30km Gridded dataset of Snowline altitude in High Mountain Asia （2001-2019）
metadata.description: High Mountain Asia is the third largest cryosphere on earth other than the Antarctic and Arctic regions. The  large amounts of glaciers and snow over the High Mountain Asia play an important role not only on global water cycle but also on water resources and ecology of the arid regions of central Asia. The snowline, as the lower boundary of the snow covered area at the end of melting season, its altitude changes can directly reflect the changes in snow and glaciers. The snowline altitude provides a possibility to rapidly obtain a proxy for their equilibrium line altitude (ELA) which in turn is an indicator for the glacier mass balance. In this dataset, the daily MODIS snow cover products from 2001 to 2019 are used as the main data source. The cloud removal of the daily MODIS snow cover products was firstly carried out based on the developed cubic spline interpolation cloud-removel method, and snow covered days (SCD) are extracted using the cloud-removed MODIS snow cover products. In addition, the MODIS SCD threshold for estimating perennial snow cover is calibrated using the observed data of glacier annual mass balance and Landsat data at the end of melting season. The altitude value of the snowline at the end of melting season is determined by combining the perennial snow cover area and the hypsometric (area-elevation) curve.  Finally, the 30km gridded dataset of snowline altitude in the High Mountain Asia during 2001-2019 is generated. This dataset can provide data support for the study of cryosphere and climate change over the High Mountain Asia.
metadata.instructions:
Named HMA_ Snowline Altitude_ 30 km_Grid, expressed as the 30 km grid snowline altitude dataset in the High Mountain Asia.
The data format is. shp, which can be opened by ArcGIS software；the fields in the data property table (2001, 2002,...2019) respectively correspond to the snowline altitude of each year from 2001 to 2019；A value of 0 represents none snowline altitude.

background: In the context of global climate change, the cryosphere's components have become a focal point of global change research, with snow being the most active component of the cryosphere, playing an important role in the global energy and water cycle due to its high albedo, high phase change latent heat, and low thermal conductivity. In hydrological and remote sensing research, the snowline is defined as the boundary line between snow-covered and snow-free areas, also known as the transient snowline. The snowline at the end of the ablation season is also commonly referred to as the snowline at the end of the melting season. In glacier and climate change research, the snowline refers to the zero balance line between annual snowfall and ablation, equivalent to the snowline at the end of the melting season. The altitude of the snowline at the end of the ablation season is considered an approximate value of the glacier mass balance line altitude and can indicate the annual mass balance of glaciers, serving as a sensitive indicator of climate change. High Mountain Asia, also known as Central Asia, is the third largest cryosphere in the world outside the polar regions and has the largest snow-covered area in the mid-latitudes, with its extensive glacier and snow distribution significantly impacting atmospheric circulation, water cycles, and radiation balance in Asia and even globally.
research objective: Using the High Mountain Asia as the study area and the developed snowline altitude dataset at a 30 km grid scale (744 grids) for the end of the ablation season, this study aims to quantitatively analyze the spatial differences in snowline altitude at the end of the ablation season in High Mountain Asia and its influencing factors. The study seeks to analyze the spatial heterogeneity of snowline altitude at the end of the ablation season in High Mountain Asia at a 30 km scale using a variogram model and to analyze the influencing factors of spatial differences in snowline altitude at the end of the ablation season in High Mountain Asia from two aspects: (1) fitting the snowline altitude of the entire High Mountain Asia and six sub-regions with three variables: latitude, longitude, and altitude; (2) exploring the impact of climatic factors (temperature, precipitation, radiation) on the spatial differences of interannual variation in snowline altitude at the end of the ablation season in High Mountain Asia and quantitatively analyzing its dominant factors.
challenges: The spatial heterogeneity of snowline altitude in High Mountain Asia is particularly strong due to the influence of complex topography. Therefore, it is necessary and urgent to quantitatively analyze the spatial dependency characteristics and influencing factors of snowline altitude at the end of the ablation season in High Mountain Asia, which can provide a basis for studying the mechanisms of cryosphere changes.
methods: In this study, the snowline altitude data at the end of the ablation season in High Mountain Asia from 2001 to 2016 was used. The entire High Mountain Asia glacier area was divided into 744 grids of 30 km × 30 km, and the snowline altitude at the end of the ablation season for each grid from 2001 to 2016 was extracted from the MODIS snow cover product. The extraction method first cloud-cleared the daily MODIS snow cover fraction product to obtain the snow cover days (SCD) dataset; then, the MODIS SCD threshold for extracting perennial snow was calibrated using glacier annual mass balance observation data and melting season Landsat data; finally, for any glacier grid, the snowline altitude information at the end of the ablation season was extracted at a large scale by combining the perennial snow area extracted by MODIS SCD with the "area-elevation" curve of the terrain.
dataset: The dataset used in this study is the snowline altitude data at the end of the ablation season in High Mountain Asia (2001-2016). In this dataset, the entire High Mountain Asia glacier area is divided into 744 grids of 30 km × 30 km, and the snowline altitude at the end of the ablation season for each grid from 2001 to 2016 is extracted from the MODIS snow cover product.
findings: The spatial distribution of snowline altitude at the end of the ablation season in High Mountain Asia shows distinct spatial heterogeneity. The snowline altitude in the inner Tibet Plateau is relatively high (5,967 m a.s.l.) and shows a small gradient of spatial variation; the lower values of snowline altitude (< 4,500 m) appear in the northern regions of High Mountain Asia (the Altay Mts. and the Tianshan Mts.); the contour lines of snowline altitude are the densest in the west of High Mountain Asia. The relative contribution ratios of the influences of latitude, longitude, and altitude on snowline altitude at the end of the ablation season are 60.5%, 2.6%, and 36.9%, respectively, and the relative contribution ratios vary for different sub-regions. Summer mean air temperature is the dominant factor affecting the snowline altitude at the end of the ablation season in High Mountain Asia, and 45.6% of the grids are influenced by summer mean air temperature and distributed in all the subregions; the grids mainly affected by annual precipitation account for about 18%, which are mainly distributed in the Karakoram Mountains and Pamir; only 10% of the grids are mainly affected by annual radiation (upward long wave flux at ground surface).

Definition.Question: What does 'snowline altitude at the end of the ablation season' refer to in the context of cryosphere research?
Definition.Answer: In cryosphere research, 'snowline altitude at the end of the ablation season' refers to the boundary between snow-covered and snow-free areas at the end of the melting season. It is considered an approximate value of the glacier mass balance line altitude and serves as a sensitive indicator of climate change, reflecting the balance between annual snowfall and ablation.

Comparison.Question: In analyzing snowline altitude, how do the challenges related to spatial heterogeneity in High Mountain Asia differ from those in other cryosphere regions?
Comparison.Answer: The spatial heterogeneity of snowline altitude in High Mountain Asia is particularly strong due to the influence of complex topography, making it necessary to analyze spatial dependency characteristics and influencing factors. This is a prominent challenge in High Mountain Asia, as it has extensive glacier and snow distribution impacting atmospheric circulation and the water cycle, which might differ from other cryosphere regions with less complex topographies or different climatic influences.

Interpretation.Question: What can the spatial heterogeneity of snowline altitude at the end of the ablation season reveal about the environmental and climatic factors affecting High Mountain Asia?
Interpretation.Answer: The spatial heterogeneity of snowline altitude at the end of the ablation season in High Mountain Asia indicates the influence of complex topography and climate conditions. It reveals that latitude, altitude, and climatic factors such as temperature, precipitation, and radiation significantly impact the snowline altitude. The variance in snowline altitude across different regions can provide insights into the mechanisms of cryosphere changes and the dominant climatic factors affecting these changes.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of MODIS snow cover data and glacier mass balance observations improve the accuracy of snowline altitude datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating MODIS snow cover data with glacier mass balance observations can enhance the accuracy of snowline altitude datasets by allowing for calibration of the MODIS snow cover days (SCD) threshold used in extracting perennial snow. This integration helps in refining the extraction process of snowline altitude by providing a more precise delineation of the snow-covered areas, which in turn improves the reliability of the snowline altitude data at the end of the ablation season.

Interpretation.Question: What methodological approaches can be employed to address the challenges posed by the strong spatial heterogeneity of snowline altitude in High Mountain Asia?
Interpretation.Answer: To address the challenges of strong spatial heterogeneity, methodological approaches such as using variogram models to analyze spatial dependency characteristics and incorporating multiple climatic and topographic variables can be employed. By fitting snowline altitude data with variables like latitude, longitude, altitude, and climatic factors, researchers can better understand the spatial differences and dominant factors influencing snowline altitude, which can provide a basis for studying cryosphere changes in High Mountain Asia.

This calibration ensures that the snowline altitude data accurately reflects the actual conditions at the end of the ablation season.

This integration refines the dataset, ensuring the snowline altitude reflects true glacier mass balance and improves the understanding of spatial differences in snowline altitude across High Mountain Asia.
